div.head: To the Honourable, Colonel TIPPING, OF WHITFIELD.
div.p:
YOU may please to remember, when I had the Honour to be in your Company last, at Soundess; part of our Discourse was upon Dedications. I believe you did not then apprehend the Danger so near. But, this Play being kindly receiv'd by the Audience; I hope it will not meet with a worse Fate, when it claims your Protection. You have known me from my Childhood, and my
Inclination to Poetry
; and 'tis from
the Happiness of that Acquaintance, I presume to make so Worthless an Offering. This also, joyn'd with your Good Humour, secures me from the Severity of your Iudgment, which gives you Power to be the greatest of Criticks. I need not tell England, how much you have always Serv'd your Country; since that would be like Proclaiming it to be Light at Noon-day. I know, all Witty Men, especially your self, hate any thing, that tends towards Flattery; therefore I shall only in Sincerity tell you: I am,

closer.signed:
Your very Humble, and most Obliged Servant,
MARY PIX.

div.head: PROLOGUE, Spoken by Mr. Penkethman, in a Press-master's Habit.
div.l: WHat Chear, my Lads? Igad, I'm come to say,
I'll press to Sea all those who Damn this Play:
Lord! how our Ship might here be Mann'd to day!
Sea-fights, 'tis thought, won't much agree with those

Whom they call Wits, and less with
Mealy Beaus
.
Mayhaps 'twou'd make them stink; for, every Year,

We don't go to drink Punch, and take
French Air.
But sure, the Gentlewomen are at rest,
None of them are afraid of being Prest.
Well, how's the Wind here? Still that's veering round,
Like your Church-Weathercocks, on English Ground,
Then hiss it goes; Oh, that's a plaguy Sound:
Igad, 'tis worse to every Actor's Ear,
Than Frets of Wind to your huge Mops of Hair.

For thus your
Cri— Criticks
serve Nine Plays in Ten,

Worse than
Jack Frenchman
does our Merchant-men.
Like Pyrates too, while honest men they're breaking,
The damn'd Fresh-water Sharks are n't worth the taking:
Yet long to maul these same New Plays as much
As we, when Homeward bound, to take a Touch;
Or, as Dubart, to snap his Brother Dutch.
Yet why shou'd they Hiss Plays not worth regarding?
Do we Bombard a Town not worth Bombarding?
Drolls shortly will amuse ye at the Fair:
To like This, think your selves already there,
As for you Spruce Gallants, pray be n't too nice,
But shew you can Oblige a Woman twice.
The First Time she was grave, as well she might,
For Women will be damn'd sullen the first Night;
But faith, they'l quickly mend, so be n't uneasie:

To Night she's brisk, and trys
New Tricks
to please ye.

div.head: EPILOGUE, Spoken by Mrs. Verbruggen.
div.l: OVR Author, by me, puts up her humble Pray'r,
This Farce, this Trifle of a Play, you'll spare.
I'll try your good Nature: But, oh! I fear
You are not like my fond Old Husband here.
Then, first, my Character who will admire?
Some will think it too cold; others, too full of Fire.
I dare swear every Spark here will say,
Damn it, that Cursed Baulk has spoil'd the Play.
Then the Ladies my Staggering won't allow,
They'l cry, Where's her strict Rules of Virtue now?
But the Ladies are not so ignorant: All know
The Difference 'twixt a Spanish Husband, and a Beau.
With Submission our Author still appears;
Courts your Indulgence, and your Iudgment fears;
Lives on your Smiles, and at your Frowns despairs.

list.head: The ACTORS Names.
list.label: Governor of Barcellona.
list.item: A merry old Lord, that has travel'd, and gives his Wife more Liberty than is usual in Spain.
list.label: Marquess of Moncada.
list.item: A Jealous Lord, Guest to the Governor.
list.label: Camillus.
list.item: A Roman Count, following the Marquess's Lady, as contracted to her before.
list.label: Colonel Peregrine.
Friar Andrew
Hidewell.
Diego.

div.stage:
Enter the Governour of
Barcellona,
and the Marquess of
Moncada.

sp.speaker: Govern.
sp.p: PRithee, my Lord Marquess, don't trouble me with thy Jealous Whims: You say, there was Masqueraders last Night under the Windows,— why there let 'em be a God's Name! I am sorry 'twas such a cold raw Night for the honest Lads. By the Honour of Spain, if I had heard 'em, I wou'd ha' sent the Rogues a Glass of Malaga to warm 'em.

sp.speaker: Marquess.
sp.p: O Lard! O Lard! I shall run mad! Sure, my Lord Governor, your Horns will exceed the largest in the Palace-Hall.— Oh! that my Wife were out of your House, and Barcellona! Methinks I am not secure, tho' she's under eleven Locks.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: By my Holy Dame, I am of your Mind: I don't think you are secure.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: How! Do you know any thing to the contrary?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Why, by th' Mass, this I believe: her Head's at work;
And I dare say, she has made ye a Cuckold,
In Imagination, with every Don she has thro'
Any Peep-hole seen, since your first Marriage.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Oh! dam' her! dam' her!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You'll never take my Advice.

lg.l: — Give but a Woman her Freedom still,
Then she'll never act what's ill:
'Tis crossing her, makes her have the Will.

sp.l: — Though! I have been in England—
There they are the happiest Husbands—
If a Man does happen to be a Cuckold,
Which, by the way, is almost as rare as in Spain:
But, I say, if it does fall out, all his Wife's Friends
Are his; and he's caress'd,— nay, Godszooks, many times
Rises to his Preferment by it.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Oh, insufferable! I am not able to bear your Discourse.
— A Man coming from my Wife's Apartments!
— Oh, the Devil! the Devil!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I see no cloven Foot he has.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: No; but he is one of his Imps; a Letter-Carrier.
I read it in his Face.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Oh! I begin to perceive it now,— here's the

Superscription writ in his Forehead:—
To the
Beauteous Donna Elenora, Marchioness

Of, &c.
Ay, 'tis very plain.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Well, Governor, these Jeers won't be put up so.

sp.speaker: Country Fellow.
sp.l: What a wannion ails ye, trow? What do ye mean by Letters? Ich am no Schollard; my Calling is to zell Fruit; and zum o' the Meads o' this Hause (Meads Ich think 'em) beckon'd me in;— I zould 'em zum; and that's all I knaw.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ay, honest Fellow, I dare swear 'tis:— why, if thou wert a Monkey, he'd be Jealous on thee.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: You may think what you please, but I fear other things.
Therefore, if, as a Guest, you will let me have
The Freedom of your House, I'll take
This Fellow in, and search him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ay, with all my Heart.— Oh these Jealous Fools!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Come along, sirrah; I'll look as much as in thy Mouth.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ay, for fear there should be a Note in a hollow Tooth.

sp.speaker: Count. Fellow.
sp.l: Why,— de ye zee, as for matter o' that,—
ye ma' look in my A—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Hold, Beast, 'tis a Man of Quality you speak to.

sp.speaker: Count. Fell.
sp.l: Zooks, I think 'tis a Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Come your ways, Impudence!

sp.speaker: Count. Fell.
sp.l: But, Sir, Sir,— must the Meads zerch me, or the Men?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: I'll tell you presently, ye wanton Rogue.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: How now, Tittup?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Morrow, Deary.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Why, Tittup, here the Marquess has been fretting,
Fuming, swearing, raging: he is just Horn-mad—
Heark ye, Tittup, did you hear any Serenading last night?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, Deary; 'twas the English Collonel to me;—
You are not angry, Deary.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l:
Not I.
Sings.

lg.l: He that has a handsom buxom Wife,
Must surely be always pleased;
Blest with a pleasant quiet life,
And never, never teased.

sp.l: But heark ye, Tittup, that English Collonel
Has such a Lear, such a Tongue, such a Nose,
Such a— have a care on him, Tittup.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I warrant ye, Deary, the honest Freedom you allow
Is sufficient: I'll never go farther.
You know, he dines here to day, and brings
His Musick to entertain us in the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes, yes; I must dispatch some business,
To be ready to receive him,— B'w'ye Tittup!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: B'w'ye, Deary: Buss, before ye go.—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l:
(Kisses her)
A pies! a pies! your Kisses glow! Fie, fie! I don't love ye.
Exit. laughing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis my Collonel, my Peregrine, sets my Heart on fire;
And gives that warmth my old Husband found
Upon my Lips— But then such a Husband,—
So good, so honest, preventing every Wish.—
— Then such a Collonel, so handsome, so young.
So charming,— Where's the Harm to give a Worthy
Begging Stranger a little Charity from a Love's Store,
When the kind old Governor can never never miss it?

div.head: SCENE, a Palace.
div.stage:
Enter Count
Camillus,
and Friar
Andrew.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Well, my Lord! now we are come to Barcellona, I fear this Devil of a Marquess will be too hard for us.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: How, Father Andrew, desponding!— 'Twas but this Morning, over your Malaga, you swore by the Eleven Thousand Virgins, and all your Catalogue of Saints, you'd bring my Elenora to my Arms.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: And by Fifty Thousand more, so I will, if it be possible: If not, my Oath is void: You know the Marquess hates me heartily, as I do him, because once he caught me carrying your Letter to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: For the good Office, I think, us'd ye most scurvily.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Scurvily! basely, barbarously; without respect to these sacred Robes; toss'd me in a Blanket; cover'd me with Filth and Dust; and so sent me by force to our Covent. For which, and my natural Inclination to Cuckoldom, I have joyn'd in your Attempts, and waited on you to Barcellona, to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You know there's Justice in my Cause.—
Elenora was, by Contract, mine, at Rome;
Before this old Marquess had her. And cou'd I agen
Recover her: I don't question but to get Leave of his Holiness
For a Divorce, and marry her my self.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Nay, that's as you please; when she's in your possession, marry, or not, 'tis all one to Father Andrew; it never shall trouble my Conscience. I must own, were I in your Condition, I should not marry; because daily Experience shows, a Wife's a Cloy, and a Mistress a Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well, we'll discourse that when we have the Lady; and in the mean time, good Father, be diligent.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: I think I am diligent; I am sure, I am worn to meer Skin and Bone in your service. This morning I found for ye a Mercury, a Letter-Carrier, that can slip thro' a Key-hole, to deliver a Billetdoux to a fair Lady,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I wish he were return'd; I fear some Misfortune has befallen him.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: O! here he comes, sound Wind and Limb!
— So, my dear Tool of Gallantry! how hast thou sped?

sp.speaker: Hidewell.
sp.p: Gad, the hardest Task I ever undertook.— Sir, you gave me five Ducats,— as I hope for Preferment, and to be made Pimp-master general, it deserves double the Sum.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nor shalt thou fall of it, Boy, if thou hast succeeded.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: First then, the damn'd old jealous Marquess caught me, and notwithstanding my counterfeit Speech and Simplicity, had me amongst his Varlets, to be search'd. They knew his Custom, and no sooner enter'd, but they flew upon me like so many Furies: I fear'd it had been to tear me Limb from Limb; but it prov'd only to tear my Clothes off; which was done in a twinkling, and I left as naked as my Mother bore me; whilst the old Marquess, grovel'd all over my habiliments, and run Pins in 'em, so thick, that a poor Louse wou'd not have 'scap'd spitting. The only thing which pleas'd me, was to observe a Peep-hole the Maids (knowing this to be their Master's Searching-room) had made; and sometimes one Eye, sometimes another, viewing my Proportions.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But had you any Letter? was that safe?
Satisfie me there.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: Pray let me take my own method.—
Nothing being found, they gave me again my Clothes,
And the Marquess a Ducat for my Trouble:
Yet I had a Letter—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Which thou ingeniously swallow'dst.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: No; which I more ingeniously brought.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What, in thy Hat?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: My Hat had the same severe Tryal.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thy Shoes—

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: They pass'd the same Scrutiny,— impossible in any of them to hide a Scrip, the least shread of Paper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: My Lord, do ye observe this Stick?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l:
(viewing it)
Yes, 'tis an honest Crabtree-stick—
I see no more in it.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l:
(taking the Stick, and putting on his Spectacles to view it)
Come, come, let me see it; I can smell out a Note that comes from a fair Hand;— By St. Dominick, here's neither Paper nor Writing upon it.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l:
Give it me.
(
He unskrews the Ferrule at the bottom, takes out the Letter, and gives it to
Camillus.)

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Thou dear Abstract of Invention, let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Excellent Hidewell! if thou wilt stay with me, whilst
I am in Barcellona, I'll satisfie thy utmost Wishes.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Here Father, here dear Confident! Orada writes:
That the tormented Marquess has remov'd her
From those Apartments that were next the Streets,
To some that overlook the Gardens,— thither,
She says, my Elenora would have me come this night;
And if they can find a place to 'scape at,
Before the Lodgings are better secur'd, they will:
If not, we shall hear of them,— a gentle Whistle
Is the Sign.— Hidewell, you shan't appear in this,
Because if seen, you'd be known agen.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Pray let me go: Gad, if the Business should be done
Without my Help, I shou'd take it very ill.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l:
Well, well, we'l in, and consider on't.
Exeunt.
sp.stage:
Scene draws, and discovers the Governor, his Lady, Collonel
Peregrine,
several Gentlemen and Ladies
.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: ALas! when Charming Sylvia's gone,
I sigh, and think my self undone:
But when the lovely Nymph is here,
I'm pleas'd, yet grieve and hope, yet fear.
Thoughtless of all but her I rove;
Ah! tell me, is not this to love?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Ah me! what Power can move me so?
I dye with Grief when she must go;
But I revive at her return;
I smile, I freeze, I pant, I burn:
Transports so sweet, so strong, so new,
Say, Can they be to Friendship due?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Ah! no, 'tis Love, 'tis now too plain,
I feel, I feel the pleasing Pain:
For, who e'er saw bright Sylvia's Eyes,
But wish'd, and long'd, and was her Prize?
Gods! if the Truest must be blest,
Oh! let her be by me possest.

sp.stage:
Collonel Peregrine
and the Governor's Lady dance; all the Time the Governor cries,
—

lg.l: Ha boy, Tittup!
Well done, Tittup!
Ha boy, Tittup!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l:
The Dance done, he goes to her,
— You are hot, you are hot Child.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A little warm.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Well, Tittup, do but carry thy Body swimmingly,
Without tripping, and we'l begin a Reformation
In Barcellona, shall thou go thro' Spain,—
The Ladies shall live like Cherubims,—
But have a care, Tittup, have a care of a faux pas.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Fear not, Deary.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Come, now let's sit down, and see the rest perform—
Let me have some lively Songs—
sp.stage:
Collonel Peregrine
goes to sit next the Governor's Lady.
sp.l: — Hold, Friend, hold! I have not learnt so much
Of your English Fashion yet, to let another man
Sit by my Wife, and I decently keep at a distance.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: I beg your Pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l:
Nay,— no harm;—
(Sings)

lg.l: If an old man has a beauteous Treasure,
Let her sing, and dance, and laugh without measure,
And then she'l think of no other Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Your own, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ay, ay Boy; I have a Thousand of 'em

In a day,
ex tempore
.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Come, now I ha' done, do you strike up.—

div.stage: The Musick ended, enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Lord, there is to wait on your Honour,—

His Excellency the Duke
Gonsalvo de Medina, de Sidoni, de
—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Hold, hold, enough, enough,— Where is he?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: In the Hall of Ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Gadso! I must go to him, sit you merry,

I'll be with you presently.
Exeunt all but Collonel
Peregrine,
the Lady, and
Spywell.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Spywell, stand at yonder Door, and give me information, as soon as ever my Lord comes up the great Stairs.

sp.speaker: Spywell.
sp.l: I will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My Angel! by Heaven I am raging mad;
Burnt up with violent Love.— Thy Shape—
Thy every Motion fires me,— but thy Eyes—
They set me in a Blaze— Oh! I must dye,
Unless the Cordial of returning Kindness save me!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Can you be so Ungenerous to wrong this noble Governor, who is so fond of you, and even dotes on me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: He wrong'd thee more, when he condemn'd thy lovely
Youth to wither'd Sapless Arms.— Can little foolish Tricks
Of fondness make amends for Extasies, Pantings,
The Joys unutterable of vigorous Love?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I must not hear ye.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You must, you must— I'll, kneeling, fix Ten thousand
Burning Kisses on thy Beauteous Hand;
And the little wanton God swims and revels in thy spritely Eyes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why am I fasten'd here!— too Rigorous Heaven!
Take from this wondrous Stranger his Conquering Charms,
Or give me more Insensibility!

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord's upon the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Away, away; mark what I say, and keep up the Discourse.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: This is but living upon the Rack;
You might contrive a better Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Peace, and observe.— But are your Ladies then so free
And yet so innocent in England?—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l:
(peeping)
— Gadso,— they are together; tho' I am not jealous, 'tis convenient to hear a little what their Conversation is.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: — Chaster in their Thoughts than your Nuns, yet merrier: more frollicksome than your Carnavals.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Very pleasant! just so I wou'd live,— yet
If a bold encourag'd Wretch once offer'd at my Honour,
I wou'd not stay to use my Husband's Sword,— but
With my own Hands stab the vile Presumer.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: You need not, Madam, talk of Weapons; your Eyes,
Tho' they roul in Fire, yet shoot chaste Beams,
And show your Heart as cold as Ice.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: So, so; very, very well, by th' Mass!
How is't my Ganymede o' the War, who look'st
Fitter to storm Hearts than Towns.— Yet, igad, you English Boys
Fear not their pretty Faces, but Fight like rugged Romans,
Or the old rough Gauls.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: You compliment us, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No faith, I hate 'em.— Well, Tittup, are ye almost ready for your Dinner?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: When you please, Deary.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I warrant the Marquess wou'd not let his Wife dine with us for the King of Spain's next Plate-Fleet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He has let me see her but once;— when I offer'd it again, he plainly told me, my Company was unfit for her:— rude Brute!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: To us who have been bred otherwise it seems a Miracle,
That men can be so barbarous to the Fair Sex.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: But I'll set 'em an Example, if Tittup holds her Ground.

— Come along—
(Sings.)

lg.l: Merrily, merrily let's pass our Time,
In Freedom, Ioy and Plenty:
At Sixty appear but in our Prime,
Whilst the Thinking Sot is old at Twenty.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE, a Chamber.
div.stage:
Enter Elenora
Marchioness of
Moncada, and Orada.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.l: Dost think the Messenger got off, Orada?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Faith I know not, Madam,— I thought I heard the Marquess's Voice as he went out.— The Fellow seem'd very cunning.—

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.l: All his Policy but little would avail him,
If my Husband met him,— by Heaven
'Tis kindly done of Count Camillus, to leave his Wealth,
His Palaces, and all the Pleasures of delightful Rome,
To follow wretched me to Barcellona.
I am a thing accurs'd by cruel Guardians,
For my Parents dy'd when I was young; they wou'd not else
Sure have forc'd me, condemn'd to an old jealous
Madman.— I saw his Follies and his Humors, and I begg'd,
Like a poor Slave, who views the Rack before him,—
All in vain; they were inexorable.— so may just Heaven
Prove to them in their greatest need!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: This is a melancholy Thought, Complaints won't break Locks; we must set our Wits at work to free our selves. I have search'd the Lodgings round, but there's no Passage; an imprison'd Mouse could scarce escape.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: But prithee, dear Orada, how got you in favour with my Lord? He us'd to hate ye abominably.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: True; and whilst he did so, it was impossible for me To serve your Ladiship.— So I wheel'd about,—
sp.l: Rail'd at you and all your Ways most heartily,
And immediately obtain'd his Grace.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: Wou'd that do?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Yes, with a bantering Letter I show'd him, pretending I had got it from you; and a long Harangue how Wives ought to hear with their Husbands Ears, see with their Eyes, and make use of no sense without Permission. In fine, I ravish'd him with my Discourse, till he threw those wither'd Sticks, his Arms, about me, and swore I shou'd remain his Heart's Joy.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: 'Tis a great Point gain'd, you must wheedle him this Night with some Story, and keep him in the Closet— whilst I watch for Camillus, or his Agent.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.l: Orada, get me the Song I love, the succeeding tedious;
Imprison'd Wretches thus count the succeeding Hours,
And groan the melancholly Time away.

lg.head: A SONG.
lg.l: BE gone, be gone, thou Hagg despair;
Be gone, back to thy Native Hell:
Leave the Bosom of the Fair,
Where only Ioy shou'd dwell.
Or else, with Misers, willing Revels keep;
And stretch thy wretched Lids from Sleep.
But hence be gone, and in thy hated room
Let Hope, with all its gentle Blessings, come.

sp.l: — So! now my Jaylor comes.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Then I'll observe my Cue.— Come, come Madam,
You must not complain.— Suppose your Husband
Kept you in an Oven, or a Cellar, you ought to be content—
I say,— Wives must submit.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Hold thy Tongue, Impertinence!—
When you were good for any thing, my Husband
Wou'd not let ye come at me: now he has brought you
To his turn, I must be perpetually plagu'd with you.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: You are a perpetual Plague to me, I'm sure—
You hate every body that tells you your Duty.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Inhuman Spaniard!— what wouldst thou have?
— Am I not immur'd, buried alive?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; I have your Body, but your Heart is with the young Count Camillus. D'ye blush, ye Strumpet, in Imaginations— Ye
Eve! Dalilan
Devil! I'll let out that bounding Blood.— Orada— get a Surgeon to take away fifty ounces.

sp.speaker: Orad.
sp.p: My Lord, you are not mad! What! have a Surgeon quiddling her white Arm, and looking Babies in her Eyes!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Monster! be thy self the Butcher, and let my Heart's Blood out: That Gentleman you nam'd has Honour, Truth, and Virtue.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Thou ly'st, false Women! he's a Rake, a Hellhound, and wallowing now in Rome's Brothels.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p:
I could contradict him if I durst.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
(laughing)
Perhaps so.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: D'ye fleer, poysonous Witch? I am going to dispatch the last Business that brought me to Barcellona. Then, Minion, thou shalt be immur'd in a remote Castle, where thou sha't not see the Face of Human-kind, except thy Women, and when I design to visit thee.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.l: Know this, and let it gnaw thy Jealous Heart:
Thy Visits will be my severest Punishment.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Watch her, Orada; preach those Maxims thy Zeal for me suggests; let her not have Liberty to think.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Fear not; let me alone to teaze her.

div.stage: Exit Marquess, locking the Doors after him.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.l: Ay,— make all fast—
Insufferable Tyrant!— Come Orada,
Let's go view the dear place, which at
Wish'd●for Night brings my dear Camillus to me.

div.head: SCENE, a Hall.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Where's this plaguy Governor? I must have him with me, because 'tis about the King's Business; tho' I hate him for breaking our Spanish Customs, in letting his Jilting Wife have such Liberty.— Ha! here she comes,— and a Spark with her;— I'll abscond, and see how virtuously she carries her self.

div.stage:
Enter Collonel
Peregrine,
and the Governor's Lady
.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I dare not stay,— my Husband thinks I am gone into my Chamber; if by any chance he should come this way, all our Hopes are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Were he by, I'd seal my Vows upon thy melting Lips— Oh! receive my Heart; it flutters near thee, and struggles for passage.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am cover'd o'er with Blushes!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
(aside, peeping)
Confound your Modesty! were you mine, you should be cover'c o'er with Blood.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: My Life! can't ye contrive some way to bless me? Your Sex were ever most ingenious lucky at Invention.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Suppose you pretended a Quarrel in England,— for which you were pursu'd, and begg'd Leave to hide here.— If you were in the House, I might get an Opportunity to visit ye,— But sure you would not be such a naughty man to ruine me, if I did.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Not for the World!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I wou'd fain love ye, and preserve my Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That is preserv'd whilst 'tis conceal'd: The Roses in your Cheeks will only wear a fresher Die,— and those dear Eyes are no Tell-tales, Love will make 'em shine and sparkle more.— I'll put your Advice in execution.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I must not venture on another moment.— Farewell.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Farewell, my Blessing.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh Women! Women! Women!— They are Crocodiles, they are painted Serpents, gilded Toys, disguis'd Fiends,— But why name I these? They are Women— Just such another is my Damsel of Darkness; if Fortune wou'd but throw a handsom Fellow in her way.— Here comes the Governor, singing, I warrant ye,— poor Credulous Fool,— I cannot but laugh— ha, ha, he!
sp.stage:
Enter the Governor singing
: Let her have her will, &c.
sp.p: — Hey da! I am glad to find you so merry. 'Tis as great a wonder to see you laugh, as 'twou'd be to see me cry— And that I han't done these Fifty Years, old Boy.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: My Lord, which is best, for a mans Wife to Cuckold him in Imagination or Reality?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Lord! Lord! your Head is always upon Cuckolding, All the Cuckolds may be hang'd, for what I care.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh fie, no! Hanging wou'd be a scurvy Death for a man of your Quality.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why— what d'ye mean by that, now, ha?— Don't provoke me, I say— do not— I shall make old Toledo
walk if you do, for all 'tis in my own House.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I must not tell him now,— It will put him so out of Humor, he won't go with me,— 'Twas only a Jest, my Lord,— I wou'd beg the Honour of your Company to the Duke of Sidonia's.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
With all my Heart— come, come:
Sings.

lg.l: Tormented still's the Iealous Fool,
Himself, nor Bosom Wife can never rest:
Yet he often proves the Woman's Tool,
Whilst the Contented Man is ever blest.

div.head: SCENE, A Chamber.
div.stage:
Enter Camillus, Friar Andrew, and Hidewell,
with a Ladder of Ropes
.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So, Hidewell! Hast thou got the Ladder of Ropes?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, here's all the Tackling.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Is it strong?— for I am something weighty.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: How, Father! just now you said you were worn to Skin and Bone.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord; but you know Bones ill cover'd will soonest be broken.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: True; take care of your self besure.— Hidewell, I have alter'd my Mind,— Thou sha't along with us; watch on the outside the Wall, and give us notice when the Coast is clear.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Let me see, have I got my Holy Water about me?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Holy Water! for what?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! I always love to say my Prayers, and have those Trinkets, when I undertake a dangerous Design.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Don't be so prophane, Domine,— you'l never thrive,— yet, if your Devotion's strong, you've time
enough— We shan't go this Hour or two.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Nay, I won't hinder ye,— an Ejaculation as I go along does the Business.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, the English Colonel, that lodges in the House, sends to know if you are at leisure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Tell him, I am,— and long to kiss his Hands.— I like that Gentleman, he appears brave
Exit Servus.
sp.l: And bold— shou'd our Designs grow desperate:
I dare believe he would not scruple his Assistance.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Faith and troth I like him too,— he treats like an Emperor; I din'd with him to day,— and he so gentilely, so agreeably forc'd Flesh upon me, that by St. Dominick, I cou'd not refuse him; tho' 'tis a strict Fast, a horrible strict Fast, as I hope to be an Abbot.— Then the obliging Toad has such a Waggish Eye, I'll pawn my beads, a plaguy Dog for the Women, and they are ever good-natur'd:— By his Holiness's Toe, I love the Sex my self,— for all this dangling Robe, and my foolish Vow of Chastity.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis pity you were not a Knight-Errant,— the Church has robb'd the Ladies of a famous Adorer.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No, faith, my Lord, I do 'em more Service in these Weeds: I have sav'd many a desperate Soul.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Thus: in procuring them the full Possession of their Desires; and that surely brought 'em to Repentance; and you know, what Repentance brings 'em to.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Truly, Father, I shall grow angry with you; for if once the Priests take up the Office of Procuring, there will be no Bus'ness for a Lay-Pimp.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Peace,— the Collonel comes.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: — I am your Lordship's humble Servant,— I have just had some Musick to complement me,— I am a great Lover of it,— if your Lordship is so, we'l have the Entertainment there.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nothing can oblige me more.— Some Chairs there!

div.stage:
A Dialogue-Song and Dances: at the time of the Dances
Camillus and Peregrine
seem in Discourse
.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: If your Lordship pleases, being in this Dress, I will aim at a Jigg, I danc'd thus once in a Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Prithee do.
A Iigg by
Hidewell.

lg.head: A SONG. Betwixt Mr. Leveridge a Spaniard, and Mrs. Cross an English Lady.

lg.l: He. FAirest Nymph that ever bless'd our Shore,
Let me those charming Eyes adore,
And fly no more, and fly no more.

She. Spaniard
, thy Suit is all in vain;
I was born where Women reign,
And cannot brook the Laws of Spain.
He. For thee my Native Customs I'll forgo,
Cut my black Locks, and turn a Beau.
She. E're I submit to be your Wife,
Listen to an English Husband's life;
With Sparks abroad I'm every day,
Gracing the Gardens, Park, or Play,
Hearing all the pretty things they say;
Give and take Presents, and when that's done,
You thank the Beaux when I come home.
He. Oh! I now my Temper fear.
She. Oh! sigh not yet, there's more to hear:
At my Levy crowding Adorers stand,
Fix'd on my Eyes, and grasping my white Hand;
All their Conrts and Oglings bent on me,
Not one regardful Look towards thee:
At this thou must be pleas'd, or else not see.
He. Then we must part, and I must die.
She. If thou art such a Fool, what care I?
He. I cannot share thee, so I am undone.
She. A wiser will supply thy Room.
Chorus. Then we must part, &c.
If thou art such a Fool, &c.
I cannot share thee, &c.
A wiser will supply, &c.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
(To the Singers and Dancers)
— So, well perform'd;— return to my Apartments, I'll be with ye presently.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The odness of our Adventures surprize me:— Both our Mistrisses in the same House!— I hope 'twill further our Designs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It must.— My Lord, I have a Favour to beg; That you wou'd lend me one of your Implements to morrow, to manage a Plot I have in agitation.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Most willingly take your Choice.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I am at your Service.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: You are so forward,— Canonical Fornication-Broker,— I believe I am fittest for the Gentleman's Service.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Goodlack, Upstart! I help'd ye to my Lord,— and now ye are for engrossing all Bus'ness to your self.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay,— I must have the most expert, because the Case is difficult.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Well! I'll not say much!— But here stands little Andrew, who has undertook to bring a Smock-fac'd Cardinal to a Maddona, secur'd with a Guard more numerous than Argus's Eyes, and more dreadful than the Dragon you wot of— yet spite of massy Doors, impenetrable Bolts, and Italian Padlocks, effected it.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Phough! what's that! I have carried on an Amour for the Queen of Spain,— convey'd her Letters made up in Wax-Candles; Love-Complaints writ in the inside of her Glove; besides a Thousand other Contrivances you never dreamt of.— 'Tis true, at last the Fate of all Court-Pimps was mine: I fell into Disgrace; as that had rais'd me, so it ruin'd me; I lost a Coach and Six by my Profession,— And shall you pretend to Rival me?

sp.speaker: Fri
sp.p: You lost! why, Sirrah, Sirrah! I tell thee, if I had imploy'd my Parts in Church-Politicks, in Tricks of Priestcraft, by this time I had been Pope.— But the bringing kind loving things together, was dearer to me than the Tripple Crown,— And shall a Varlet contend with me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Gentlemen! dispute no more; I find either of you is qualified for my purpose.— My Noble Lord, good Night,— if you want me, on the least notice, I am ready.
Exit Col.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I thank you, dear Neighbor, good Night.— Hidewell, take up the Ropes, and come away.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Along, Blunderbuss.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: I hope, Father Peremptory, before to morrow Morning, you'l stand in need of my Cunning, to deliver that lov'd Carcass from some imminent Danger.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I defie thee, and all thy shallow Imaginations.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Leave jangling, and make haste.

div.head: SCENE, a Palace.
div.stage:
Enter the Marquess
, Orada
following him
.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: — My Lord, I have a Thousand things of greater consequence to say.— Pray return.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Dear Orada, by and by; I must see where my Devil of a Wife is.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: You know she cannot pass the Lodgings, perhaps she's at her Devotions.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: No, she's too foul to Pray.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
(Taking him by the Arm)
— But, my Lord,— as I was saying,—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
(Flinging from her)
I'll return immediately.—

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: There's no keeping this mad Fool out of his Wife's sight;— They must e'en to Bed, whilst I parle with the Lover.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: — So, Gentlewoman! I have caught ye!— How? With your Head out at Window, making your amorous Complaints!

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: I was almost stifled for want of her.— Sure you are not Jealous of the Trees and Stars,— They were my only Objects.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh Impudence! did I not hear you say, When will he come; my Light, my Life, break thro' this Veil of Darkness, and shoot with Rays of Comfort on me?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
(aside)
A duce of these thinking Minds! so brimfull of Cogitations, they must run over.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: I knew you behind me, and therefore did it to torment ye.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: It may be so; but I sha'n't trust ye— Come, into the Bedchamber.— Orada, do you School her,— I'll watch for your Light and Life my self.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: My Lord, you had better go to Bed with her, and then you'll be secure.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
No, no; in, in.
(Shuts 'em in and locks the Door)
— Now for my Pistols— that I may give this Midnight-Guest the Welcome he deserves.
Exit.

div.head: SCENE changes to an Orchard.
div.stage:
Count Camillus
and Friar
Andrew
come down the Wall by a Ladder of Ropes.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: — So!— We are got well in; Heaven send us safe out agen!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Father, Father! don't trouble Heaven in this Affair, you'l never prosper.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Bless me, my Lord! Prayers are natural to me: if you are so wicked to neglect 'em, I can't help that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come, mind your Bus'ness: where's the Whistle?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
Here, here,— now for a delicious Vision, Of a peeping Angel!
Whistles.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
The Signal's given, and here's the Answer.
Shoots off a Pistol.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: We are discover'd; and if I stay, all other Opportunities are left for ever.—
sp.stage: A Cry within of Thieves! Thieves!
sp.p: — Why Friar! Friar! Father! You are not hurt, the Bullets went over our Heads.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Are ye sure I am not hurt?— I did conceive I was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
No, no; but I know not what you may be if you stay— Follow me, with speed.
Cam.
gets over the Ladder
.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
Oh Pox! the Devil of all ill Luck! ruin'd, hang'd,
When the Friar is halfway up, the Ladder breaks, and falls down.
drawn, and quarter'd! No possibility of escaping without a Miracle,— and I can't have the Impudence to expect a Miracle.—
Noise within, Where! Where! Thieves follow.
— Oh! they come! they come!— and now at my greatest Extremity I cannot pray.— God so! here's a Tree!— I'll try to mount it.
Gets up the Tree.

div.stage: Enter the Marquess, and several Servants.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Search well, Boys! leave not a Shrub or Tuft of Grass unexamin'd— Five Pistoles to him who finds One.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.p: I warrant ye, my Lord! let us alone for ferreting 'em!— Soho! what have we here— A Pox, 'tis a Stub of a dead Tree— 'thas broke my Nose.

div.stage: (Another Servant looking up in the Tree, where the Friar is.)

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p:
Oh Rogue! Are ye there? I'll be with ye presently.
(Friar Andrew,
as the Fellow gets up, throws his Bottle of Holy-water full in his Eyes, and pulls his Cowl over his Face, and roars out: They both fall from the Tree together.
)
— The Devil, the Devil! oh, my Eyes are out!
The rest cry, The Devil!
They drive the Marquess in, who often turns, and cries:
Let me see him! let me see him!

div.head: SCENE changes to the inner part of the House.
div.stage:
Several Servants enter in Confusion,— a great knocking at the Door, and cry of
Fire, Fires
One of the Servants open the Door,— Enter
Hidewell,
Men and Maids, as from their Beds— some crying,
Fire, some Murder, Treason,
&c. After them— Enter Friar
Andrew,
driving several Servants, who run out, crying,
the Devil! the Devil!

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: — Make haste, unlucky Devil!— 'Twas I cry'd Fire! open'd the Door for your deliverance— Fly, and own me for the Master of your Art for ever.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
I cannot stay to thank ye,— But— I yield, I yield.
Exit running.

div.stage: Enter the Governor, in his Night-Cap, and Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Benedicta Maria
! What! Fire, Murder, and Treason all abroach at once!— a horrible Plot!— By the Honour of Spain, a terrible one, as I hope to be a Grandee!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Saywell, what can be the meaning of this? My Collonel would not come in such a way.— My Lord! my Deary! the Matter,— the Cause of this Disturbance!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Here, Sirrah! raise all the Guards: Oh Tittup! we're like to be murder'd,— drown'd, and blown up, no body knows how, nor which way: A damnable Plot! by his Majesty's Mustachoes I swear!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sure 'tis a false Alarm,— The House has been searcht by some Servants discreerer than the rest,— and they find nothing.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Villains! Dogs! under the notion of the Devil,
These Sheep-lookt Rogues, these Dastard Whelps,
Have let the Robber of my Honour escape; whilst I
But just examin'd if my Wife was safe, the Wolf, the Goat is gone.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Hey da! my Lord Marquess, Are we then alarm'd only with a jealous Whim of yours? By the Peace and Pleasure of my Life, I'll suffer it no longer.— Any other of my Palaces are at your Service; but such a Wasp shall molest my Honey-hive no more.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Uncivil Lord! thy Palaces, nor all thy Wealth shou'd bribe my stay,— To morrow I've resolv'd for my departure,— in the interm, I desire an hours Conference.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Soon as you please, I am free.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, here we've found a man that no body knows.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ha! who are ye, Sirrah? Your Name? From whence d'ye come? Whither d'ye go? What's your Business?— Answer me all at once.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p:
I daut I caunt,— but I'll do no more than monny a Mon; I will tell ye the truth: Coming to Morket with my Fruit, d'ye zee, Ich heard the noise of
Fire, Fire! Thieves
, ond such-like,— zo che thought good Crabtree-stick might walk amongst the Rogues; zo Ich have left the Fruit with our Margery, and come with main Vorce to help ye, d'ye zee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: An honest Lad! and, d'ye hear, you may sell your Fruit to my Family.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: O Lard, O Lard! Ch'am a made Mon, and my Wife and Children: what! zell my Fruit to my Lord Governor— made for ever! henceforth I'll scorn my Neighbors, and despise my Betters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I like this Fellow, because I search'd him throughly, and found him no Go-between.— Here, Sirrah! there's something for ye,— and were I to stay, ye shou'd ha' my Custom.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: I thank your Honours.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
(to a Sentinel)
Let him out.
Exit Hidew.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Youll remember to morrow morning early.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Most certainly.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
(aside)
Then I'll convince this credulous easie man what need there is of watching one's Wife:— Good-night.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Farewell; go thy ways, for a troublesome, maggot-pated, jealous-crown'd Simpleton, as thou art:— Hey boy, Tittup! how is't Tittup? how shall you and I get to sleep again Tittup? ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
What, moody, Tittup!
(Sings)

lg.l: I'll rouse ye, and mouse ye, and touse ye as long as I can,
Till squeaking I make ye confess:
There's Heat in a vigorous Old Man,
When he loves to excess, when he loves to excess.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Curst be my disappointing Stars, that thus have cross'd me! whilst I but aim at Elenora's Freedom; she, for my Attempts, suffers from her Tyrant-Husband worse usage.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: You may curse your Stars, if you please; but for my part, I bless the pretty twinkling Gentlemen,— that is, if they had an hand in my Deliverance.— I am sure, if I had been caught, my Usage would have been bad enough.— I long to know what is become of that Hangdog Hidewell.— Oh!— talk of the Devil, and he appears.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: — Down on your Marrow-bones, Domine, and thank my Ingenuity, else your brittle Thread had been cut; and you left in a dark way by this time.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Come, come; don't be so triumphant:— for had not my own roaring Preaching Voice—

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Ay, ay; much us'd to Preaching, I believe,— unless it was Indulgence to a yielding Female.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Well, as I was saying, had not my own Almighty Voice struck Terror thro' 'em, I had been in Limbo, long before your Ingenuity came to my Assistance.— Not but you did me a Kindness,— and I acknowledge it,— That's enough for a man of my Qualifications.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh Hidewell!— all my Hopes are ruin'd, and poor Elenora must remain a Slave for ever.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p:
My Lord, you are mistaken,— our Expectations now stand fairer; the Governor and Marquess both take me for a very silly honest Fellow,— and have order'd I shall have full and free access;— then let me alone for a Contrivance.— I'll get the Lady for you, and the Woman for
my self; following the Example of all noble Knights, and trusty Squires.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: I find you are providing for your selves: But what must I have for my Pains-taking in this Affair?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.l: You know, you cannot marry;— I'll give you leave
To tempt my Damsel, when I have her: D'ye conceive
— If she loves Spiritual Food, I'll not be your hind'rance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Dear Hidewell! thou sha't go immediately; learn when they remove; fathom their Designs; I'll force her from him on the publick Road.— He forc'd her from her plighted Faith, her Vows, and all her Wishes: My Force is just.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Trust to me, my Lord, and fear not.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Lord! your humble Servant! I ha'n't rested to night, since I heard of your Disappointment, reflecting how my own Affair may prove.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ah Colonel! our Cases are very different,— You hunt but for Enjoyment, the huddl'd Raptures of a few tumultuous moments:— But I am in quest of Virgin-Beauty, made mine by Holy Vows; constrain'd by Fiends, instead of Friends, to break the sacred Contract, and follow the Capricio of a mad Old Man.— Virgin did I call her?— By Heaven, I dare believe she is one, at least her Mind is such;— and were she in my power, I'd soon convince the World of the Justice of my Cause.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Lord! you shall command my Sword and Interest in Barcellona,— yet you must give me leave to mind my own Affairs.— I grant your Passion more Heroick;— for I shou'd scarce accept the Governor's Wife for mine, if he wou'd give her:— but I am amorous and eager, as Love and Beauty can inspire hot and vigorous Youth.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: By St. Dominick, well said, old Boy: I'll stick to thee. I hate these whining Romantick Lovers. Nor wou'd I have trudg'd to Barcellona, had I thought the Count only fix'd on Honora,— Psha, I can get it out,— Honourable Love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Since you are so willing, Sir,— I have Employment for
you.— Can you play the Hector well, pursue with a fiery Countenance, swear without intermission, make noise enough, no matter what you say?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: I'll try, I'll try,— hum! hum!— by St. Dominick, by St. Patrick, St.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Hold! hold! what d'ye mean? You must swear by
Iupiter, Radamanthus, Mars
, and those blustering Sparks; not such puny passive Saints.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Well, Sir,— I shall be soon instructed:— But what must I swear all this for? or like the Bullies of the Age, must it be all for nothing?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, no, there is a Cause;— Come along with me— and I'll give ye Clothes, and full Directions.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: If I might advise ye, Sir, he should not undertake it; he has something in that unlucky Phy's shows him unfit, tho' coveting Intrigues: plaguy unfortunate Lines, I swear.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Peace Envy! Scrietchowl! Raven! Bat! Devil! When did I ever fail before that Night? nor then neither, sirrah, ha!

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Rage on, Spight! I say but this.— Have a care, when in all your Gallantry, you don't forget, and make a Friar-like Salutation.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Pox take ye for putting me in mind on't— for, I always do a thing I am forbid.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Please your Honour, a Lady desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'll wait on her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'll leave you this Apartment free, my Lord; my Business being in haste.— Come, Father!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Farewell: may your Desires be fulfill'd, or you cur'd of 'em.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: B'w'ye Hidewell! I don't question but to top you in my Performance when we meet next.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p:
Heaven help the weak, I say.
Exeunt Col. and Friar.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ha, my dear Orada! What Miracle got thee this liberty?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: My Lady was so throughly frighted at the noise of the Pistols, and the Confusion she heard, (for you, I suppose) that she has since been ill.— The jealous Marquess cou'd not find in's Heart to trust a Doctor with her, but sent me for a Cordial.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I hope her Sickness has no Danger in it.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: No, no; 'tis over now,— scarce enough left for a Pretext for, my coming.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, what Hopes? What shall be our next Design? Speak Comfort, my best Friend!

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Faith, I know not well:— Suppose the Marquess were some way inform'd, you are in Barcellona,— 'twou'd fright him out of his Wits;— I'd back it, and perswade him to send Elenora in the night privately, lest you attempt her on the Road,— then you may seize the unguarded Fair.— Methinks something like this might be done.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: We'l in, and consider farther on't.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Heark ye, Donna, if your Lady falls to my Lord, you prove my natural Perquisite, by the Example of a Thousand Years.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: What means the Fellow?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Despise him not, Orada; he has prodigious Parts under that Russet Coat.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: I care not for him, nor his Parts, I shall ne'r examine 'em.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: You and I shall be better acquainted for all this.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Away, Bumpkin!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I tell ye he's a Beau in Disguise.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Come to this inner Room, Orada, lest we are interrupted.
Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE, a Hall.
div.stage:
Enter the Governor, Marquess, and
Diego.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A-pox, a-pox! Was this your Conference?— If I had guess'd at it, the Devil shou'd have confer'd with ye for me.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I wou'd ha' thank'd a Friend that sorewarn'd me, of an approaching Evil.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Evil! What Evil? The Evil is my knowing it; if I had not, 't had been none.— Yet how am I convinc'd you have not abus'd my Tittup:— By the Honour of Spain, I'll Fight for Tittup: Guilty or not Guilty.— My Lord!— what you have said is a scandalous, contagious, outragious,—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Hold,— if you say one word more, I draw.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, well!— I will have Patience,— but if this Colonel doth not come with the Sham-plot you have buzz'd into my Head, by King Philip's Beard,—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Threaten not; Ill meet you when and where you please, ill-manner'd Fool!
Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Diego! I have born up,— yet, Igad, to own the Truth, I am damnably afraid— there's something in it.— That English Colonel is a plaguy Dog; he looks as if he were made to enter all Breaches, conquer every way.— I'll try if I can sing after this News.
(Sings)

lg.l: Lock up a Woman, or let her alone;
Keep her in private, or let her be known:
'Tis all one, 'tis e'en all one.

sp.p: — A scurvy Tune, as I hope to be a Grandee.— Nay, if my Voice is broke, my Heart will quickly follow●— Diego!

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I ever found thee faithful;— if the Spark does come, follow exactly my Directions, and all shall be well yet.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Fear not me, my Lord, I'd lose a Leg or an Arm at any time in your Honour's Service, and never cry, Oh! for't.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Heark, heark! I think I hear a Noise.
Cry of Fire here.

div.stage: Without, a Cry of Murder, and shutting Doors.

Enter Col.
Peregrine,
his Sword drawn, leaning upon his Servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, my Noble Lord! I'm ruin'd, unless your Pity save me: in England I, in a Duel, kill'd a Gentleman, and his Friends have pursu'd me hither, setting upon me, Four at once.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Alas and welladay! 'tis sad indeed! and you, I warrant, are wounded desperately.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I fear, to death,— oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Ah, the dissembling Rogue! it grieves me almost to disappoint him, the Smock-fac'd Dog does it so cunningly.
aside
— Diego!

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Diego, get one of my able Surgeons to search the Wound.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I thank you, my Lord; my own Servant has great Skill in Surgery, I'll trust him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Diego! carry this Gentleman to an Apartment near the Garden, free from Noise,— I'll send Tittup to visit ye by and by.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Your Lordship's all Goodness.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And thou all Treachery,— Oh! the English whineing Dog— how shall I punish him? By the honour of Spain, he deserves to be utterly disabl'd,— render'd wholly incapable.— But I'll have Mercy in my Anger: hang't— I have lov'd the handsom Whipster, and he shall find it.
— So,— have ye dispos'd of him as I order'd?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord; and whilst I was in the Chamber, he groan'd as if his Heart were breaking,— But I had the Curiosity to stay a little at the Door, and heard both laugh ready to burst, an't please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Please me! not much, in faith, Diego; but— let me tell 'em, had they fell into the hands of any other of our Nation, their Mirth wou'd quickly ha' been spoil'd, and their Whoring too adod.

div.stage:
Enter Servants, hauling in Friar
Andrew.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
My Lord, we have took the Ringleader, that pursu'd the Noble
English Colonel
.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Good Boys! Good Boys!— Well, Sir,— And what are you?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
If you are a man of Authority, as by your House and
Port I guess you are, I charge you, do me Justice; for by yonder blew Firmament, and all those hated Stars, that twinkl'd at my Brother's Murder, I'll flea that cursed Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Thou Hangdog, begot in Lewdness, and born in some Sink of Sin,— Son of a thousand Fathers, and Maker and Contriver of Cuckolds without number; I know thee for a Pimp: Here, Diego! fasten upon one Whisker, whilst I take t'other; if they are fast, I may alter my Opinion— They are reverend Whiskers, I confess,— if not, I proclaim thee a Pimp.

div.stage: They pull, and the Whiskers come off between'em.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh, mercy! mercy! I do own my Profession; but good my Lord, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ay, that I will, but I'll punish thee first,— here,— carry him to the red Tower, and let him have Two hundred Lashes, till all Thoughts of Concupiscence, either for himself or others, be throughly mortified.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Hear me, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, away with him.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: You must hear me; I am a Priest, I excommunicate ye else.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A Priest, and a Pimp! Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Why? is that such a Wonder?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Look, my Lord! here hang his Beads under his Clothes.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, you are satisfied the Secular Arm can't punish me; pray give me a Release.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Hold, hold, not so fast.— Take him, and carry him to the next Abby just as he is, and tell the Fathers what ye know.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: 'Tis well 'tis no worse,— to deal with the Tribe, let me alone, they'l judge my Frailties by their own.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Say ye so, Beelzebub, in his own Cloathing! but I'll be a Thorn in thy side, I'll warrant thee, old Father Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, we'll set the Mob upon him, that's worse than all the Justices in Quorum.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
I'le Curse, Excommunicate, Purgatory ye, Hang ye, Damn ye.
Exit forc'd off.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
My
Deary, Spywell
tells me our dear Colonel's wounded.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh, most dangerously, Tittup; he has as many holes thro' him as a Jew's Cake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas, then I fear he's dead.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no; Nature has fram'd his Body for the purpose; a Sword passes and repasses like a Jugler's Ball, and no harm done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Cruel Deary! you make a Jest on't, but I'le visit and comfort him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Hold, hold; his Wounds are dressing: You wou'd see him naked, wou'd ye?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh Gad! not for the World.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Retire to your Chamber, I'le send for you when 'tis convenient.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will, Dear; but pray take care of him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Yes; there shall be Care taken of him, I promise ye.— A hopeful young Gentleman, by the Honour of Spain.— Diego! follow to my Closet, there I'le make thee sensible of my Design.
Exeunt.

div.stage:
Enter the Marchioness
Elenora, meeting Orada.

sp.speaker: Elen,
sp.p: Dear Orada! bring'st thou Comfort, or must I remove from Barcellona to Wilds and unfrequented Desarts, impenetrable Castles, and all the melancholy Mischiefs spritely Youth can fear?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: I hope not, Madam; the Lord Camillus employs his Brain and all his busie Instruments, for your deliverance.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: Give me the Scheme of his Design, that I may guess at the Success.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
Madam,— my Lord.—
Enter the Marquess.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
Take that— thou impudent Performer of my Tyrant's Will,
Strikes her.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: My Lord, you see what I suffer for your Service.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
But we'll be so reveng'd, Orada; when we have her wholly to our selves, by Heaven, I'll bring that pamper'd Carcass down: The Roses shall wither in her wanton Cheeks; her
Eyes, whose hot Beams dart Fire, grow dull and languid:— By all my Pangs of Jealousie, I'd rather clasp a Fiend, than Doubting Sleep by such an Angel.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: And 'tis thy Doubts, Old Man, not I, torment thee— Our Sex, like Water, glides along pleasant and useful; but if grasp'd by a too violent Hand, unseen they slip away, and prove the fruitless Labour vain.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: To Waters, Waves, and Rocks most justly may you be campar'd;— but I want time to hold an Argument.— Prepare this Night for your remove,— I am fix'd,— your Jewels, Equipage and all put up.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
Let my Slaves take care of that,— What need have I of Jewels, Ornaments, or Dress, condemn'd to Cells and everlasting Solitudes?
Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, a Country Fellow is very importunate to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Bring him in,— Mistress, you to your Chamber. You hear the man's Business is with me.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
May it prove a vexatious one, I beseech Heaven.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: — Oh, my honest Fruiterer, what brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Why, an't shall please ye,— a marvellous thing has hapt since I see ye last,— a parlous Contrivance, by th'Mess,— as I hope for Margery, I ne'r see the like.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: The matter, Friend!

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Nay, Gadsores, 'tis zo strange, I can't tell whether I was asleep or dreamt, or no.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Prithee tell me quickly; what Wonder hast thou met with, Fellow?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Zir, I'm but a poor Fellow; but, as Neighbour Touch has it, I can zee into a Milstone, as var as another man.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Talk to the purpose, or I shall grow tir'd:— is it any thing concerning me or my Honour?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Zir, you don't know the bottom of this Plot.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Nor the top on't neither,— dallying Fool, proceed.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Nay, you'l know it soon enough:— Han't you a very handsom Wife, buxom and free, as the Saying is?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, lies it there? Well! what follows?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: I●ags, Cuckoldom, ch'am afraid, Zir,— for coming out of this Hause, there meets me a waundy handsom Fellow, Gadsores,— he had the swinginst— what d'ye call't.—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Perruque, d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Ay, udslid! our biggest Bushel, that's kept on purpose for the Masters of the Measures to zee, wou'd not,— no, i sacks, ch'um zure— it wou'd not cover it.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Did he enquire after my Wife?

sp.speaker: Hidew,
sp.p: By my troth he did.— Friend, says he, do you go often to that House?— Mahap I do,— mahap I do not, said I, what's that to you? Nay,— no harm, quoth he; and thereupon slipt a piece of Gold into my Hand.— I must confess that soften'd me,— and he went on,— Dost thou not know an old jealous, freakish, confounded Marquess lives there? Pray ye now dan't be angry, Sir,— I use but his own words.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: No, no, go on.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: And has he not, quoth he, a young lovely Wise?—. And then he run on with hard words, I cou'd not conceive for above a quarter of an hour, tho I was wise enough to pick it out, that he was Amour'd on her.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Confound him, confound him!

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Quoth he,— Canst thou convey a Letter to her?— Why how now mon, zed I, who dost take me for, a Pimp? No, no, ch'am no Pimp,— an I war chou'd ha' better Cloas o' my Back,— by th' Mess, chall do none o' your Bawdy Messages, not I; Do't your self, an you wull, for Tim. With that he drew his Sword, and I very vairly took up Heels, and run away, for ch'am very veard of a naked Sword.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Couldst thou not discover his Name?

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p:
His Zervants call'd him— Count— a—
Cam— Cam— Cam
— ch'am zure 'twas zummot about Cam.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
(starting)
What,— Camillus!

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that's it, that's it, in troth.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Oh, I am ruin'd, blown up, undone! Camillus has his Pockets cramm'd with Gold;— he'll bribe the World to take his part:— Then that Contract— so firm and sure,—
I lose her, and what I value more, her large Fortune.— Orada, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Suppose ye remove my Lady in a Litter, without any of your own Attendance,— for indeed I fear he'll way-lay all the Roads.— My Lord, she may be got many Leagues this night, and when in safety, you may send back for your Equipage.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Many Leagues! we'll go a Thousand,— for I'll be with her, and force her speed.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
(aside)
That I suspected.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Zir, Zir, here che may serve ye, for I keep a Litter, as well as zell Fruit.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh! thou'rt an honest Fellow; and, fear not, you shall be rewarded beyond your Wishes:— Come in,— I'll give thee an Order for one of my best Horses, because my Servants shall not suspect 'tis for my self. Orada! get your Lady ready,— 'tis now near Night, and it shall be done with speed.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Be sure you lame the Horse now; for as soon as the Litter has lost sight of the Marquess, we return into the City, and towards the Morning escape in a Felucca already order'd,— whilst the disappointed Marquess is Hunting the Roads in vain.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Madam, I desire none of your Directions, I am perfect Master of my Trade.— I cannot but think how bravely I shall maintain thee. Girl; for Mony comes rowling in.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Mind your Business, and think of Fooling afterwards.

div.head: SCENE, a Chamber.
div.stage:
The Scene draws, and discovers Col.
Peregrine
upon a Bed, and his Man by him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I begin to grow damnable weary of nursing up this no Wound; I wish the dear Angel wou'd but come, and heal the real Wound my Heart endures.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I shou'd have but little Stomach to a Mistress, if I were in your circumstances:— What! attempt to Cuckold a Spanish Governor in his own House!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Peace Coward, and see who's coming.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, 'tis my Lord Governor.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, well— Oh! oh! oh!

div.stage:
Enter Governor and
Diego;
speaks aside to
Diego.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Diego! unobserv'd secure that Sword, Hat, and Perruque,— I shall have use for't.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How d'ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, very bad,— just, just fainting.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Please ye to have some Cordial, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A little, if ye will.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And are not you a damn'd dissembling handsome Toad— Answer me that now,— answer me that. What! corrupt the Wife of my Bosom, my Darling Tittup! break the Laws of Hospitality! Well,— thou'rt a desperate Fellow, I protest;— design to Cuckold one that hopes to be a Grandee of Spain!— Abominable, by St. Iaques! Come, come, get up; your Wound's not mortal, I'll engage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'm so confounded, I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ay, I thought 'twou'd come to this,— Now shall I be toss'd in a Blanket, burnt, drown'd, hang'd!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Be quiet, Rascal, and be damn'd!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What, you'r out of humour, Sir! I must confess, 'tis a plaguy disappointment. Come, in short, I'll use ye much better than you ought to expect. Go with haste and privacy to your Lodgings, and the Town shall know nothing of the matter:— Your Wig and other Accoutrements shall be sent after ye; but I must use 'em first.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg your Pardon for this Attempt; you know ' ● has been no more.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Your Goodwill was not wanting, thanks to your whoring Stars.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Tho' unarm'd, I will not stir from hence, if you practise a thousand Cruelties upon me, unless I have your Promise, that you will not hurt your Wife.— I have Honour, tho' the Rules are now transgress'd. Nor can I leave a Lady (whom my Love has entic'd) to the Resentments of a Spanish Husband.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
An Honourable Dog, as I hope to be sav'd! by all that's sacred, I will not hurt her; only she must remain depriv'd of
that Liberty, which, against our Country's Custom, I had given her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That I'm sorry for; but cannot ask more.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: But I shall ask you to be gone.— Diego— get one of my closest Chairs, and let him be convey'd home, as sick.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, I cou'd tear my Flesh.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, fast and mortifie it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I own you generous, but have not the Heart to thank you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I tell ye once again— your Absence will best express your Acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Oh, your very humble Servant, sweet Friend in a corner!— Now, Diego! help to equip me.
Exit Colonel.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The Perruque, the Perruque block— oh, how the amorous Rogue has perfum'd it,— the Pulvil, Essence, and Powder o'ercomes me.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: My Lord, may I presume to tell ye,— your black Beard, and that white Perruque look very disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
No matter, the Curtains will hide that.— Now go to my Wife, and tell her, I am gone to the Castle, to see the Guards reliev'd, and shall sup there.— Tell her also, I desire she wou'd visit the wounded Colonel in my absence.—
Exit Diego.
— Now I shall find if Tittup knew the bottom on't, and were consenting to this Roguery.
Throws himself on the Bed.

div.stage:
Enter his Lady, and
Spywell
her Woman
.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, we are happy beyond what we cou'd expect; my Husband sups at the Castle to night,— yet I tremble every Limb of me:— I swear I love this old Governor, and nothing but this charming Englishman cou'd have tempted me to break my Vows.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p:
Madam, you walk and talk, you know not where— you are in his Chamber.
Goes towards his Bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: — My Love, my Life, wilt thou not meet me? there is no further need of Counterfeiting.

div.stage: Governor leaps up, and snatches her Hand.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ungrateful Tittup!

His Lady
.
(shrieking
)
Ah!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How couldst thou serve me so?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Phogh, I knew 'twas you, and did it on purpose to make you jealous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A pies, a pies, no, no, you did not know 'twas I:— I wou'd be deceiv'd, but cannot.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, what must I expect?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Diego!— first turn this Baggage out o' doors,— and d'ye hear Mistress,— if ye tattle of these Affairs, I'll have ye poyson'd,— else ye are free and safe.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Madam, farewell; I can't excuse my self.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now my Turn's a coming.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ah Tittup! whither, whither art thou fallen?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
(crying)
No, Deary, not fallen, I was but staggering— and you caught me Deary.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: For which I humbly conceive, you wish me hang'd, Deary.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed Deary, I'm glad my Honour's safe;— I never had an Inclination before, and never will again, if you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I'll take care you shall never have another Opportunity; your back Apartments must be your Prison, and an old Dovegna your Companion, till Time and Age have wrought off your loose Desires. No more hoity toity,— no more appearing at Windows,— dining at Deary's Table, and dancing after it for Digestion.— I say, Tittup, all these Vanities must be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! stab me first! Let me not be a May-game to all my Servants, who by my Confinement wou'd guess at my Disgrace. You us'd to swear you lov'd your Tittup— I never did a Fault before, but what a Frown might punish— Now let me experience your boasted Fondness; and take me to your Heart, with kind relenting smiles— else leave me distracted on the Earth in endless fears bemoaning my Indiscretion, and your Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
(aside.)
I feel I begin to mollifie!

To her.
Oh,
Tittup, Tittup
! Thou hast been a Baggage! a
very Baggage— by the Honour of Spain!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I confess I have been frail— But I will be forgiven, so I will— I'll hang about thy Neck; nor leave the dear Place 'till my Pardon's sign'd.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What! Give you again your Freedom to see another Colonel, and be again betray'd?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No; there is not such another Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How, Tittup!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not such a Tempter; such a Seducer, I meant.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Thou pretty Epitome of Womans weakness— I dare not trust thee— Tittup— you must retire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do, lock me up; and next moment you are gone, I'll hang my self in my own Garters, so I will.— Can you behold your Tittup hang'd? her Eyes gogling, her Mouth, you have buss'd so often, gaping; and her Legs dangling three Yards above Ground?— This is the Sight you must expect.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh! I can't bear the thoughts on't— Stand farther off— farther yet— that I may rush upon thee with all the vigour of Sixteen, and clasp thee from such a Danger— Thou resistless Ruler of a doting, fond, old Fool!— Here— I forgive thee— but if after this, I catch ye staggering, expect no Mercy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: By the new Joys, your returning Kindness brings me, I'll die first!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The World may blame my Conduct; but then— they know not Tittup's Charms; the Power of her Eyes, and Pleasure of her Arms.— I cannot raise my Voice to sing, yet— hum!— No; Gad, zooks, 'twon't do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Henceforth

lg.l: Good Humour shall supply thy want of Youth,
You shall be always kind, I full of Truth.

div.head: SCENE, a Hall.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: Do we succeed, my dear Orada?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
Beyond expectation, Madam— within some moments, you are in Camillus's Arms.— Hidewell is gone for
a well-appointed Litter, which wheels but round, whilst Hidewell plays Tricks with my Lord; and then carries you to the English Embassador's.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: Now my Desires are so near fulfilling, I begin to fear 'em— yet I know Camillus is Honourable.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: All's Honourable. The House is Honourable, the Lady Honourable: Fear nothing, but in, and Pray for our Success— I think I hear my Lord— You must be sure to seem very unwilling.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
I'll warrant ye.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Is your Lady ready?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. But, good Lord! what a life have I had with her— I believe she has thrown Fifty things at my Head— She swears she won't go like a Thief in the Night.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh! when the Litter comes, we'll do well enough for that— I'll make her go, or leave her dead upon the place.— Dost thou think none of the Servants perceive our Preparations at this Back-door?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
My Lord, there's no Danger— 'tis so far through the Gardens; and now we have these Apartments, their People never come at 'em.
Enter Hidewell.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Here comes my trusty Fellow well! hast go a Litter?

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: Ay; and by th' Mess, an able one too— I worn ye Mon, afore day, we be past whistling after.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Friend, you never talk'd to a Lord in your life, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Pho, pho! 'tis all well— Is the Horse for me ready too?

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: Just by the Litter, my Lord!— my Lord— i fackens it saunds rarely.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Call Elenora.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p:
I will venture— but Heavens! how I shall be us'd!
Exit, and Re-enter with
Elenora.
— Nay, Madam, 'tis in vain disputing it; for you must and shall.

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: A vine Dame, by th' Mess!

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
Commanded by my Slave! Monster! whither dost thou
intend to have me at this dead hour of Night? to Death, I hope.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: To Death, if you resist— Orada, hall her along.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: I think I do pull her— I believe her Arm will come off.

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: Why law ye, Mistress— dan't be so veard— Ye shall come to no hort— I have had vine Vokes in my Litter' vore naw.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: Away, Fool! leave halling me— I will go— thou cruel Devil!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Come, I'll see her in the Litter; and then take Horse.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Sirrah! Sirrah! where's my Horse?

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: My Lord! my Lord!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Sot! Dunce! my Horse!

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: Why a— why a— I ty'd him to the Pales— and tis so waundy dark without, I cannot find him.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Fly and search! Bid the Litter go softly: I'll oretake 'em.

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p:
I'm gone, I'm gone—
(Comes back.)
— My Lord, must I bring him hither?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Eternal Fool! Call to me, and I'll come out.
Hide stopping.
Udsookers! ' ch'am zummat a veard.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: This Fellow will make me mad— Beast! will ye stir!

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: Ch'ave heard Vokes talk of Ghosts, zo I have, about the Park Pales.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Rascal! I'll make a Ghost o' thee; if thou dost not go, or direct me, where my Horse is.

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p:
I run, I run!
Exit. The Marquess following him.

div.stage:
Hidewell
crosses the Stage running: the Marquess within cries, Where are ye?

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p:
I'll lead him a Dance— Here, here!
Exit.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
A Pox, where?
The Marquess Entring.
— Oh! the Devil! I can't wag a step further! I have lost sight of him, and the Litter; and am lam'd into the Bargain— I hope Orada, observ'd my Directions for the Road— The Pass I gave 'em, lets 'em through the City Gates: If this Fool wou'd come once, I shou'd soon overtake 'em.— Numps, Fool! Are ye coming?

sp.speaker: Hidewell
sp.p:
within.
O Lard! O Lard! ch'am an undone, Mon! Gh'am an undone, Mon!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What's the matter?

div.stage:
Enter Hidewell
leaning on his Stick; as soon as he comes in, he falls down, and roars out.

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What ails the Fellow? Where's my Horse?

sp.speaker: Hide.
sp.p: A Murrain, a Plague take your Horse— ch'am maim'd for ever— For getting up to make haste, he has thrown me, and broke my Leg. Oh, my poor Wife and Children! they must to the Parish— Then Margery— how she'll take on! for, to zay truth, I lov'd her better than my Wife— Oh! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
The Devil take thee, and all thy Family, for an unlucky Dog! I see, I must call up my Servants at last.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Hidewell,
sp.p:
getting up.
Farewel, sweet Signior! for, by this time, your Lady's in safe Hands.
Exit hastily singing.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Pedro! Olonzo! Valasco!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Did you call, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Yes. A Fellow has broke his Leg— You must wake Monsier Cureclap, my French Surgeon— and, Olonzo, give Orders to my Grooms this moment, to prepare two Horses; Valasco shall go with me.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: My Lord! what Fellow? Where is he? Why, here's no body!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
(looking about.)
Gone! Hell and Furies! A Plot upon my Honour, my Life, my Wife, my Estate! Murder! Murder! Saddle all my Horses; get what Friends Money will purchase; search every Road— my Estate! my Wife! Hell and Damnation!

div.stage:
Enter Governour, with a Letter in his hand: His Lady,
Diego,
and Servants
.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So! the Cry's up agen— but Heaven be thanked, 'tis almost over now— What's the matter, my Lord Marquess?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Ruin'd, undone for ever! My Wife's Run away!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How! Run away! That's worse than I, Deary.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I know not: 'Tis according as you prove, Tittup— A bad Wife's better lost than found.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Unkind Deary.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: My Lord, burying all Animosities, I beg you wou'd assist me now. I shall run mad— my Wife, nay more, a great Estate, lost! lost!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: My Lord, you must be pacify'd— I've ill News to tell you— there's a Letter sent me from Rome, by the Cardinal Patron of Spain; that you stole a Young Lady, firmly contracted to a Noble Roman Count: Also His Majesty's Order to put the Lady in a Monastery, till your Cause is try'd.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
I'll Hang my self! I'll Drown my self! I'll Bury my self alive! Dogs,! Whelps! get me Cords, Knives, Poyson, Sword, and Fire.
Exit Raving.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: The Man's distracted— Diego, after; and perswade him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis a just Judgment on him, Deary, for being so Jealous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ay, Tittup; when Women never give any cause, you know, Tittup.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hump!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord Camillus a sends to give you an Account, that he expects the Lady Elenora at the English Embassador's. He hears, by an Express, your Honour has Orders from the King relating to her; to which he willingly submits.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: An honest Lad, by the Honour of Spain— Tell him, Friend, I'll wait on him immediately at the Embassador's.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Deary.
Exit Gentleman.
