sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What now! That begging look's put on for something.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let me go with you, and see the Embassador's Lady, and the Marchioness, and—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: — And the English Colonel. Ha! why, Tittup, canst thou look me in the Face, and ask this?— By the Honour of Spain, I believe this Hoity, Toity will desire me to admit him for her Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly, Deary, if the Colonel is there, you shall hear me charge him, never to see me more.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A new way, Tittup! to go into a man's Company, to forbid him your sight! Come— thou sha't along! and—

lg.l: If with Horns my Kindness thou dost repay,
I'll Punish thee some unknown, uncommon way,
Nor hear whate're thy Charming Tongue can say,

div.head: SCENE changes to the English Embassador's.
div.stage:
Camillus meeting Elenora and Orada:
Runs and Embraces
Elenora.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My Elenora! art thou here! do I hold thee fast, thou choicest Blessing of my Youth!

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: Witness my Heart, which strongly beats, how much I'm pleas'd in my Camillus's Arms! But, Oh! I blush, when I remember I am another's Wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No more o'that; the Cardinal's my Friend, and has promised a Divorce immediately— Therefore Crown my Joys with Smiles, and forget past Dangers.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: I can say only this: I love ye—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And not descending Angels, with all their Heavenly Tunes, cou'd Charm like that dear sound!— safe in a Monastery thou shalt remain, till the Dispute is ended. And then— Oh! thou blest Charmer— then all my Sufferings shall be liberally paid; and longing Love Revel in Feasts of unutterable Delight.— Nor art thou forgot, dear Orada, but, whilst I have Life, sha't be us'd like a Friend, and Mistress of my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Orad.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Honour, and heartily rejoice at my good Lady's Happiness.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Poor Hidewell!— I hope he is in safety.—

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: — Yes; and here, at your Honour's service,— tho' I have had a broken Leg, and two or three other Misfortunes,— but alls well now, and I can dance for Joy.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thou art a witty Rogue,— and henceforward sha't ha' no occasion to expose thy self, ● I'll provide for thee like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p:
I'm your ready Slave,— D' ye hear that, Mrs. Scornful?
(To Orada)
how d' ye like my Parts and Person now?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.p: Troth I've seen so much between my Lady and the Count, that my Mouth almost waters.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: We shall soon agree, I find.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
My dear Elenora, the Ambassador's Lady sends
A Lady enters and whispers
Camillus.
word, her Husband is gone for a few days to hunt: she is very ill, but that all things in her House are at your service.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: To morrow I'll wait on her.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Friend! here's the lovely Prize, which so well deserves the Pains I have taken.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A charming Lady!— My Lord, you are a happy man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How goes your affair, and what's become of the obliging Friar?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, Heaven knows! the Story is too long to tell; only this: I found the old Lord generous, and resolve to attempt his Wife no more.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'm glad on't— in your Age you never will repent an uncommitted Sin.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: That Governor's Lady seem'd a pretty good-humour'd Creature; therefore, my Tyrant, let me see her but once

div.stage:
Enter Friar
Andrew,
his Clothes torn, and cover'd with Dirt, and his Face scratch'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Who have we here! Oh Heavens! Father Andrew!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What! my Hector thus us'd!

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: What has befaln thee, oh thou weak Brother?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
(angrily)
What has befaln me! you may behold what has befaln me; Dirt, Wounds, and Disgrace.— The Ladies may live in Rat-Traps, or dye o' the Pips, for Father Andrew's Assistance again.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: Look, forward Undertaker and wretched Performer, there the Lady stands, deliver'd by me!

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: My Lord, is not this the Friar brought your first Letter, after I was married, whom the Marquess caught and abus'd?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The same, Madam

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: I said he had unfortunate lines, but he wou'd take no warning.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p:
Not to encourage any thing that's ill, but because you have suffer'd in my Cause, there's a Cordial will revive the Heart, and wash out all Stains.
Gives him a Purse of Gold.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
For me you have suffer'd too; and I beg you wou'd accept of this.
Gives him more.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Spite of Vows, in this Necessity there's no refusing such a Favor.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come, Father, cheer up your self, have recourse to your old Friend Malaga,— I'll provide for ye, that you shall go thro no more Dangers.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
By St. Dominick, I had not need; for I have almost lost my Life in this.
Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Governor of Barcellona is come to wait on ye.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Gods me— in, Father! you wou'd not see him, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
See him! I'd sooner see the Devil:— Well, I'll get a pretty Wench to wash me without, and good store of Malaga within, and try to forget past Sorrows.
Exit.

div.stage: Enter Governor and his Lady, Arm in Arm.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: My Lord, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yours in all Obedience.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
(aside)
— Yonder he stands,— the Ogling Rogue! I thought so.— My Lord Camillus, before I talk to you, pray give me leave for some few words with that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, o'th' t'other side, if you please,— Now, Tittup, speak what you promis'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Colonel Peregrine, my Lord has been so good to forgive me what is past; and I desire, for the future, as you are a Gentleman, you wou'd, after this night, never see me more.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, I obey.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And d'ye hear,— if ye prove a Man of Honour, about Threescore Years hence I may leave ye Tittup for a Legacy, and abundance of Wealth, a World of Wealth, by the Honour of Spain.— Nay, 'tis worth staying for.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Threescore years hence, quotha!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Now, my Lord Camillus, to you and the Lady.
They go aside.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: I wish we had some Musick,— since our Success, I can't keep my Heels on the Ground.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If the Company agree to it, I can procure my Lord Ambassador's, and send for my own.

sp.speaker: Hidew.
sp.p: I'll motion it presently.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: I freely submit, and will retire to what Monastery you appoint. I hope my future Conduct will satisfie the World of my Innocency.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And mine, of my Faith and Constancy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
What say ye now to Musick and Dancing?
Hidewell Songs.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: With all my Soul, this is a Jubilee, which I'll keep whilst I've life.

sp.speaker: Elen.
sp.p: But are we secure?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Fear not, Madam; my Guards surround the House,— and am not I here?
They all sit.

div.stage: Songs and Dances: Them over, the Company comes forward.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Greatness was the Attendant of my Birth;
But Love gives me Heaven upon Earth.
These Comforts my Elenora does impart:
Joy to my Eyes, sweet Raptures to my Heart.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Like you, here stands a happy Man;
And I'll keep my Tittup,— that is, if I can.
